basics.name: Himal Shrestha
basics.label: Bioinformatician
basics.summary: A PhD graduate in Bioinformatics with expertise in computational and mathematical modelling. I am passionate about using data to predict, prevent, and eliminate infectious diseases. Currently, I work as a bioinformatician in the MDU-PHL, University of Melbourne. My research at La Trobe University involved studying the transmission of parasitic disease, called river blindness, by integrating genomic, environmental, and epidemiological data with a variety of modelling and analytical approaches.

education.area: New tools for onchocerciasis elimination in Africa: the role of spatially explicit models in informing decisions.
courses: Random Fields: Mathematical theory and application in spatial statistics

education.area: Thesis: Analysis of ivermectin action on adult female Onchocerca volvulus from embryogram data: evidence for reproductive periodicity and the basis for the embryostatic phenotype.
Thesis: Assessment of C-Reactive Protein/Albumin ratio for predicting outcome in critically ill patients with various underlying diseases.
education.studyType: Bachelor of Science in Human Biology

work.name: MDU-PHL, The University of Melbourne
work.summary: Developing and maintaining bioinformatics pipelines for the analysis of genomic data from bacterial pathogens

work.name: Nematode and Vector Genomics Lab, La Trobe University
work.summary: Formulating empirical and/or mechanistic transmission models utilising genomic, environmental and epidemiological data and supervise students working on related research.

work.name: La Trobe University
work.summary: Demonstrating and tutoring masters and undergraduate students.

volunteer.summary: Started organisation to facilitate research activities between students and researchers in the field of bioinformatics and biotechnology in LMICs and HICs.
highlights: Organised Python workshops for Master's in Bioinformatics student at Pokhara University, Nepal
Helped with development of projects with Internation Vaccine Institue (IVI), South Korea

awards.title: Best poster prize
awards.awarder: Asia Pacific Consortium of Mathematics for Industry (APCMfI)
awards.summary: Awarded for the poster presentation on 'Parameterising vector movement in an onchocerciasis transmission model with population genetic data' which included a month-long research visit to the ICIAM conference in Tokyo and Kyushu University in Fukuoka, Japan.

publications.name: Synthesizing environmental, epidemiological and vector and parasite genetic data to assist decision making for disease elimination
publications.summary: This article presents a framework for mapping and analyzing the transmission of vector-borne diseases, specifically onchocerciasis, by integrating environmental, epidemiological, and genetic data of vectors and parasites1. The study focuses on the ecological transition zone in Ghana, highlighting the importance of coordinated disease intervention efforts over large geographic areas to eliminate transmission of onchocerciasis.
